Author: designer#4893
Content:
the Internet was created as a distributed system. but 30 years later, it is a monopoly structure that is hard to see in any existing industry. this is because the revenue model of the Internet is based on advertising. Internet content is free. but consumers have to be exposed to numerous ads. 

the reason why this has happened is because the Internet did not support micro-payment technology. true small payments should be made at 10cent to 20cent, free of three things: cumbersome procedures such as membership registration, personal exposure to financial information, and transaction fees. 

no matter how much online shopping grew, payments were forced to go through the financial network because the Internet did not have the technology to support payment services on its own.

bitcoin showed the possibility of micro-payment without going through financial network. the emergence of corporate-guaranteed cryptocurrency such as Libra will also facilitate micro-payments. 

micropayments change the structure of the Internet. If an article, a webcomic and a video can be paid in small amounts, a portal-like hub that can attract advertisers to one place will no longer be needed. 

In other words, the possibility of small payments could bring down global IT dinosaurs such as Facebook, whose advertisements are a major source of income. In other words, Facebook has taken a step closer to self-destructive territory.

Facebook's logic to persuade the government and intellectuals at the hearing is also likely to be related. this means that the situation is so desperate. 

from the moment bitcoin came into the world, the rules of the game began to change. It's just a matter of adjusting to the new rules and surviving.

zuckerberg will persuade the government to allow Libra, saying it cannot stop blockchains like BTC and ETH.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Do big tx fees really matter?  I think about the tx fees i pay on gasoline... they are large.  In part probably because the first oil companies became the biggest and it suited them to have large tx fees

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: i think about all the tx fees behind a cob of corn from the supermarket (corn subsidies, bureaucratic bullshit, multiple levels of taxes) and they are high

Author: Hollowman9000#3344
Content: For pop miners they matter

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: i think there is an argument to be made that if you are first to market, command a lions share of it and have vendors already sinking costs into integrating your service...  high tx fees dont seem to be a killer

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: i am not very familiar with ETH tx fees, so i am kinda talking out of my ass here, but I would imagine they pale in comparison (percentage wise) to almost any other significant transactions we make in our lives using fiat

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Taxi fare you are paying the cabbie, the union, the government, toll roads, friggin everybody

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: insurance companies, politicians
